title: Projective spaces
content: Looking at a corner in 3D space, one can see three right angles. It is impossible to draw three lines in 2D space such that any two of these lines are perpendicular, but a good enough representation is made by casting lines from the 2D surface. Points along the same cast line are collapsed into one point on the 2D surface. In many cases, the 2D surface is smaller than whatever needs to be represented. If the lines cast were perpendicular to the 2D surface, then only areas as small as the 2D surface could be represented. To fix this, the lines need to get further apart as they go farther from the 2D surface. On the other side of the 2D surface the lines will get closer together and intersect at a point. (Because it's defined that way). From this perspective, two parallel lines in 3D space will be represented by two lines that seem to intersect at a point "at infinity". Considering all maximal classes of parallel lines on a 2D plane in 3D space, these classes will all appear to intersect at different points at infinity, forming a _line at infinity_. Therefore the _real projective plane_ can be thought of as the real _affine_ plane together with the line at infinity. The projective plane takes care of some exceptions that may be found in the affine plane. For example, consider the curve that is the zeroes of ` y = x ^ 2 ` . Any line connecting the point (0, 1) to the x-axis intersects with the curve twice, except for the vertical line between (0, 1) and (0, 0). In the projective plane, the curve becomes an ellipse and there is no exception. While it may not seem like it, points at infinity and points corresponding to the affine plane are the same type of point. Consider a line going through the origin in 3D (affine) space. Either it intersects the plane ` z = 1 ` once, or it is entirely within the plane ` z = 0 ` . If it is entirely within the plane ` z = 0 ` , then it corresponds to the point at infinity intersecting all lines on the plane ` z = 1 ` with the same slope. Else it corresponds to the point in the 2D plane ` z = 1 ` that it intersects. So there is a bijection between 3D lines through the origin and points on the real projective plane. The concept of projective spaces generalizes the projective plane to any dimension.

df-prjsp
blocks.content: Define the projective space function. In the bijection between 3D lines through the origin and points in the projective plane (see section comment), this is equivalent to making any two 3D points (excluding the origin) equivalent iff one is a multiple of another. This definition does not quite give all the properties needed, since the scalars of a left vector space can be "less dense" than the vectors (for example, equivocating rational multiples of real numbers). (Contributed by BJ and Steven Nguyen, 29-Apr-2023.)

axiom df-prjsp(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cprjsp, cmpt(s0, clvec, csb(s1, cdif(cfv(cbs, cv(s0)), csn(cfv(c0g, cv(s0)))), cqs(cv(s1), copab(s2, s3, wa(wa(wcel(cv(s2), cv(s1)), wcel(cv(s3), cv(s1))), wrex(s4, cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, cv(s0))), wceq(cv(s2), co(cv(s4), cfv(cvsca, cv(s0)), cv(s3))))))))))
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
}

  ‚ä¢ PrjSp =(s0 ‚àà LVec ‚Ü¶[((Base ` s0)\ {(0 ` s0)})/ s1](s1 /. { < s2, s3 > |((s2 ‚àà s1 ‚àß s3 ‚àà s1)‚àß ‚àÉ(s4 ‚àà(Base `(Scalar ` s0)), s2 =(s4[(√ó ` s0)]s3)))}))
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)

  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)

blocks.name: prjspval
blocks.content: Value of the projective space function, which is also known as the projectivization of ` V ` . (Contributed by Steven Nguyen, 29-Apr-2023.)

thm prjsprel(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5) {
  |- wb(wbr(c0, c1, c2), wa(wa(wcel(c0, c3), wcel(c2, c3)), wrex(s0, c4, wceq(c0, co(cv(s0), c5, c2)))))
  -| wceq(c1, copab(s1, s2, wa(wa(wcel(cv(s1), c3), wcel(cv(s2), c3)), wrex(s3, c4, wceq(cv(s1), co(cv(s3), c5, cv(s2)))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)

  -| diffss(s0, s3)

  -| diffsc(s3, c0)

  -| diffsc(s3, c4)
  -| diffsc(s3, c5)
} = {
  brabg2a(s1, s2, c0, c1, c2, c3, c3, wrex(s0, c4, wceq(c0, co(cv(s0), c5, c2))), wrex(s3, c4, wceq(cv(s1), co(cv(s3), c5, cv(s2)))))
  cbvrexdva(s3, s0, c4, wa(wceq(cv(s1), c0), wceq(cv(s2), c2)), wceq(cv(s1), co(cv(s3), c5, cv(s2))), wceq(c0, co(cv(s0), c5, c2)))
  eqeq12d(cv(s1), co(cv(s3), c5, cv(s2)), c0, co(cv(s0), c5, c2), wa(wa(wceq(cv(s1), c0), wceq(cv(s2), c2)), wceq(cv(s3), cv(s0))))
  simpll(wceq(cv(s1), c0), wceq(cv(s2), c2), wceq(cv(s3), cv(s0)))
  oveq12d(cv(s3), c5, cv(s2), cv(s0), c2, wa(wa(wceq(cv(s1), c0), wceq(cv(s2), c2)), wceq(cv(s3), cv(s0))))

thm prjsper(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, clvec), wer(c1, c2))

blocks.name: prjspvs
blocks.content: A non-zero multiple of a vector is equivalent to the vector. (Contributed by Steven Nguyen, 6-Jun-2023.)

} = {
  3eqtrd(cfv(cprjsp, c0), ciun(s0, c1, csn(cdif(cfv(c2, csn(cv(s0))), csn(c3)))), cqs(c1, copab(hs0, hs1, wa(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), c1), wcel(cv(hs1), c1)), wrex(hs2, cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(hs2), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs1))))))), ciun(s0, c1, csn(cec(cv(s0), copab(hs0, hs1, wa(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), c1), wcel(cv(hs1), c1)), wrex(hs2, cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(hs2), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs1))))))))), wcel(c0, clvec))

blocks.name: cprjspn
blocks.content: Extend class notation with the n-dimensional projective space function.
blocks.origin: const class cprjspn { PrjSpn }

blocks.name: diff.cprjspn.s
diff.cprjspn.c
diff.cprjspn.w
df-prjspn
blocks.content: Define the n-dimensional projective space function. A projective space of dimension 1 is a projective line, and a projective space of dimension 2 is a projective plane. Compare ~ df-ehl . This space is considered n-dimensional because the vector space ` ( k freeLMod ( 0 ... n ) ) ` is (n+1)-dimensional and the ` PrjSp ` function returns equivalence classes with respect to a linear (1-dimensional) relation. (Contributed by BJ and Steven Nguyen, 29-Apr-2023.)

thm 0prjspnlem(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cdr), wcel(c1, c2))

} = {
  3eltr4g(c1, c2, cfv(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), nat0), cdif(cfv(cbs, c3), csn(cfv(c0g, c3))), wcel(c0, cdr))
  syl(wcel(c0, cdr), wcel(cfv(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), nat0), cdif(cfv(cbs, c3), csn(cfv(c0g, c3)))), wcel(c0, cnzr))
  drngnzr(c0)
  mp3an23(wcel(c0, cnzr), wcel(cfv(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), nat0), cdif(cfv(cbs, c3), csn(cfv(c0g, c3)))), wcel(co(nat0, cfz, nat0), universe), wcel(nat0, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)))
  ovex(nat0, cfz, nat0)
  eleqtrri(nat0, co(nat0, cfz, nat0), csn(nat0))
  snid(nat0)
  c0ex()
  fz0sn()
  sylanbrc(w3a(wcel(c0, cnzr), wcel(co(nat0, cfz, nat0), universe), wcel(nat0, co(nat0, cfz, nat0))), wcel(cfv(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), nat0), cdif(cfv(cbs, c3), csn(cfv(c0g, c3)))), wcel(cfv(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), nat0), cfv(cbs, c3)), wne(cfv(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), nat0), cfv(c0g, c3)))
  syl3an1(wcel(c0, cnzr), wcel(co(nat0, cfz, nat0), universe), wcel(nat0, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), wcel(cfv(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), nat0), cfv(cbs, c3)), wcel(c0, crg))
  nzrring(c0)
  uvccl(c0, co(nat0, cfz, nat0), universe, nat0, co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), cfv(cbs, c3), c3)
  uvcn0(c0, co(nat0, cfz, nat0), universe, nat0, co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), cfv(c0g, c3), c3, cfv(cbs, c3))
  eqid(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)))
  eqid(cfv(cbs, c3))
  eqid(cfv(c0g, c3))
  eldifsn(cfv(co(c0, cuvc, co(nat0, cfz, nat0)), nat0), cfv(cbs, c3), cfv(c0g, c3))
}

blocks.content: In the zero-dimensional projective space, all vectors are equivalent to the unit vector. (Contributed by Steven Nguyen, 7-Jun-2023.)
